Yes, of course. Filmmakers should be held accountable for perpetuating harmful stereotypes and insensitive portrayals, regardless of the historical context. It's important to recognize that art doesn't exist in a vacuum, and that the portrayals we see on screen can have a real-world impact on how we perceive other people and cultures.

Filmmakers have a responsibility to create works that are both socially conscious and respectful of the experiences of marginalized individuals. They should strive to avoid perpetuating harmful stereotypes and instead work to create representations that are nuanced and respectful of diversity.

At the same time, it's also important to recognize the value of analyzing and critiquing art from the past. By examining the problematic portrayals of historical films, we can better understand the ways in which past prejudices and biases have shaped our society and our cultural productions. By learning from the mistakes of the past, we can better work towards creating a more inclusive and just future.
